page.title: 07THE COASTLINE,LOWER PENARTH.
page.content: Geologically the coastal landscape from Penarth Yacht Club to Lavernock Point consists of{Rhaetic black shales with{fossil}bivalves,a thin bone bed, red and green{marls and sandstones from the Triasic Era.In the strata, examples of faults and folding can be seen.The undercutting action of the sea is clearly seen at{Lavernock Point The beach is covered mainly by pebbles but a few patches of{sand}can be seen and{wave_cut platforms}are in evidence at the point.{Groynes}have been built. to prevent the movement of deposited material.As such a tidal range occurs here,a retaining wall has been built.A study concerned with the building of a {Barrage}from Lavernock to the Somerset Coast is now being conducted.The muddy shore means animal life is rare,but we find Crabs,Seaweeds,Sandhoppers,in the Flotsam at the High Water Mark.
